sen.j: 法住寺（ほうじゅうじ）は日本の京都市東山区にある天台宗の仏教寺院である。
sen.e: Hoju-ji Temple is a Tendai Sect Buddhist temple located in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City.
Hoju-ji Temple is a Tendai Sect Buddhist temple located in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City.
Hoju-ji Temple is a Tendai Sect Buddhist temple located in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City.

tit.cmt: 表記を他の記事と統一

sen.j: 平安時代中期に藤原為光によって創設され、その後院政期にはこの寺を中心に後白河天皇の宮廷「法住寺殿」がいとなまれた。
sen.e: It was founded in the mid Heian period by FUJIWARA no Tamemitsu and, following this, Emperor Go-Shirakawa centered his court at the temple as 'Hojuji-dono Palace' during his period of cloistered rule.

It was founded in the mid Heian period by FUJIWARA no Tamemitsu and, following this, Emperor Go-Shirakawa centered his court at the temple as 'Hojuji-dono Palace' during his period of cloistered rule.
It was founded in the mid Heian period by FUJIWARA no Tamemitsu and, following this, Emperor Goshirakawa centered his court at the temple as 'Hojuji-dono Palace' during his period of cloistered rule.

sen.j: 法住寺殿が源義仲によって焼き討ちされ、数年を経て後白河上皇もなくなると、法住寺は後白河上皇の天皇陵をまもる寺として江戸時代末期まで存続、明治時代期に御陵と寺が分離され現在にいたる。
sen.e: Hojuji-dono Palace was set ablaze by MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka, Retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa passed away several years later and Hoju-ji Temple continued to serve as his mausoleum until the end of the Edo period when the tomb and temple were separated in the Meiji period.

Hojuji-dono Palace was set ablaze by MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka, Retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa passed away several years later and Hoju-ji Temple continued to serve as his mausoleum until the end of the Edo period when the tomb and temple were separated in the Meiji period.

Hojuji-dono Palace was set ablaze by MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka, the Retired Emperor Goshirakawa passed away several years later and Hoju-ji Temple continued to serve as his mausoleum until the end of the Edo period when the tomb and temple were separated in the Meiji period.
sen.cmt: the Retired Emperor Goshirakawaとしました。

sen.j: 寺内の『身代不動明王（みがわりふどうみょうおう）』像は、平安期の作風とされる。
sen.e: The temple's statue of "Migawari Fudomyoo" is in the Heian period style.
The temple's statue of "Migawari Fudomyoo" is in the Heian period style.
The temple's statue of "Migawari Fudomyoo" is in the Heian period style.

sen.j: この不動像は寺伝では慈覚大師が造立したといわれ、後白河上皇の信仰も篤かった。
sen.e: According to temple legend, this statue was created by Jikaku Daishi and devoutly worshipped by Retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa.
According to temple legend, this statue was created by Jikaku Daishi and devoutly worshipped by Retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa.
According to temple legend, this statue was created by Jikaku Daishi and devoutly worshipped by the Retired Emperor Goshirakawa.
sen.cmt: the Retired Emperor Goshirakawaとしました。

sen.j: 義仲の放火のさいに、上皇の身代わりとなったと伝えられており、現在も毎年11月15日には不動会（ふどうえ）がいとなまれる。
sen.e: The statue is said to have been used as a substitute for the retired emperor when the temple was set ablaze by Yoshinaka, and is at the center of the Fudo-e festival that is still held every November 15.

The statue is said to have been used as a substitute for the retired emperor when the temple was set ablaze by Yoshinaka, and is at the center of the Fudo-e festival that is still held every November 15.

The statue is said to have been used as a substitute for the retired emperor when the temple was set ablaze by Yoshinaka, and is at the center of the Fudo-e festival that is still held every November 15.

sen.j: 988年(永延2年)、太政大臣藤原為光が法住寺の落慶法要をいとなんだことが『日本紀略』『扶桑略記』などにみえる。
sen.e: It is known from "Nihonkiryaku" and "Fuso Ryakki" that Grand Minister FUJIWARA no Tamemitsu held Hoju-ji Temple's 'rakkei hoyo' (a memorial service to celebrate the construction of a temple) in the year 998.

It is known from "Nihonkiryaku" and "Fuso Ryakki" that Grand Minister FUJIWARA no Tamemitsu held Hoju-ji Temple's 'rakkei hoyo' (a memorial service to celebrate the construction of a temple) in the year 998.

It is known from "Nihongi Ryaku" (Summary of Japanese Chronologies) and "Fuso Ryakki" (A Brief History of Japan) that Grand Minister FUJIWARA no Tamemitsu held Hoju-ji Temple's 'rakkei hoyo' (a memorial service to celebrate the construction of a temple) in the year 988.
sen.cmt: 『日本紀略』『扶桑略記』の表記を修正しました。

sen.j: 寺域の釈迦堂には本尊金色丈六釈迦如来、薬師如来、観音菩薩、延命菩薩、如意輪菩薩、法華三昧堂には普賢菩薩、常行三昧堂には阿弥陀如来が安置され、円融天皇をむかえて豪華な法要がいとなまれた。
sen.e: The temple's Shaka-do Hall houses a 1-jo, 6-shaku (approximately 480 cm) tall statue of Shaka Nyorai and statues of Kannon Bosatsu, Enmei Bosatsu and Nyoirin Kannon Bosatsu; the Hokke Sanmai-do Hall houses a statue of Fugen Bosatsu; the Jougyou Sanmai-do Hall houses a statue of Amida Nyorai; and the temple would put on lavish ceremonies for Emperor Enyu.

The temple's Shaka-do Hall houses a 1-jo, 6-shaku (approximately 480 cm) tall statue of Shaka Nyorai and statues of Kannon Bosatsu, Enmei Bosatsu and Nyoirin Kannon Bosatsu; the Hokke Sanmai-do Hall houses a statue of Fugen Bosatsu; the Jougyou Sanmai-do Hall houses a statue of Amida Nyorai; and the temple would put on lavish ceremonies for Emperor Enyu.

The temple's Shaka-do Hall houses a "one jo, six shaku" (approximately 480 cm) tall statue of Shaka Nyorai and statues of Kannon Bosatsu, Enmei Bosatsu and Nyoirin Kannon Bosatsu; the Hokke Sanmai-do Hall houses a statue of Fugen Bosatsu; the Jougyou Sanmai-do Hall houses a statue of Amida Nyorai; and the temple would put on lavish ceremonies for Emperor Enyu.
sen.cmt: 1-jo, 6-shaku→"one jo, six shaku"に書き換えました。

sen.j: 為光は985年(寛和元年）に妻と花山天皇の女御であった娘を相次いでうしなっており、その菩提を弔う目的でこの寺を創建したという。
sen.e: In the year 985, Tamemitsu lost both his wife and daughter, Emperor Kazan's court lady, and it is said that he founded a temple to pray for their happiness in the afterlife.
In the year 985, Tamemitsu lost both his wife and daughter, Emperor Kazan's court lady, and it is said that he founded a temple to pray for their happiness in the afterlife.
In the year 985, Tamemitsu lost both his wife and daughter, Emperor Kazan's court lady, and it is said that he founded a temple to pray for their happiness in the afterlife.

sen.j: 為光は現世の栄達をすて、ここで念仏三昧の生活をおくった。
sen.e: Tamemitsu rejected his worldly fame and resigned himself to a life at the temple absorbed in a prayer to Amitabha.
Tamemitsu rejected his worldly fame and resigned himself to a life at the temple absorbed in a prayer to Amitabha.
Tamemitsu rejected his worldly fame and resigned himself to a life at the temple absorbed in a prayer to Amitabha.

sen.j: 992年(正暦3年)、為光の死にあたっては「封戸100戸」が寺に寄進された。
sen.e: The temple was donated 100 "sustenance" households (fuko) following Tamemitsu's death in the year 992.
The temple was donated 100 "sustenance" households (fuko) following Tamemitsu's death in the year 992.
The temple was donated 100 "sustenance" households (fuko) following Tamemitsu's death in the year 992.

sen.j: 為光死後、しばらくのあいだ法住寺は子孫によってまもられていたが、1032年(長元5年)、九条邸から燃えひろがった火災によって焼亡。
sen.e: After Tamemitsu's death, his descendants protected the temple for a time but it was destroyed in 1032 when fire spread from Kujo-tei.
After Tamemitsu's death, his descendants protected the temple for a time but it was destroyed in 1032 when fire spread from Kujo-tei.
After Tamemitsu's death, his descendants protected the temple for a time but it was destroyed in 1032 when fire spread from the Kujo-tei residence.

sen.j: このあと約120年間、大規模な再建などの記録はみられない。
sen.e: There are no records of any large-scale reconstruction works having taken place for approximately the next 120 years.
There are no records of any large-scale reconstruction works having taken place for approximately the next 120 years.
There are no records of any large-scale reconstruction works having taken place for approximately the next 120 years.

sen.j: 1161年(永暦2年)から、藤原為光が建立した法住寺を中心とした地域に、為光の寺院を包摂するかたちで後白河上皇の御所がいとなまれる。
sen.e: From 1661, the Retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa exerted cloistered rule from the area around Hoju-ji Temple, constructed by FUJIWARA no Tamemitsu, including the temple itself.
From 1661, the Retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa exerted cloistered rule from the area around Hoju-ji Temple, constructed by FUJIWARA no Tamemitsu, including the temple itself.
From 1161, the Retired Emperor Goshirakawa exerted cloistered rule from the area around Hoju-ji Temple, constructed by FUJIWARA no Tamemitsu, including the temple itself.
sen.cmt: ハイフンをとり、Goshirakawaとしました。

sen.j: これが法住寺殿である。
sen.e: This was Hojuji-dono Palace.
This was Hojuji-dono Palace.
This was Hojuji-dono Palace.

sen.j: その敷地は十余町、平家をうしろだてにした上皇の権威で、周囲の建物はとりこわされ、広大な敷地に南殿、西殿、北殿の三御所がつくられた。
sen.e: The site was over 10 hectares in size, and the power of the Retired Emperor who also backed the Taira family allowed him to demolish the surrounding buildings to create an expansive estate in which the three Imperial palaces, Nan-den, Sei-den and Hoku-den (Southern Palace, and Western Palace, Northern Palace), were built.

The site was over 10 hectares in size, and the power of the Retired Emperor who also backed the Taira family allowed him to demolish the surrounding buildings to create an expansive estate in which the three Imperial palaces, Nan-den, Sei-den and Hoku-den (Southern Palace, and Western Palace, Northern Palace), were built.

The site was over 10 hectares in size, and the power of the Retired Emperor who also backed the Taira family allowed him to demolish the surrounding buildings to create an expansive estate in which the three Imperial palaces, Nan-den, Sei-den and Hoku-den (Southern Palace, and Western Palace, Northern Palace), were built.

sen.j: 狭義の法住寺殿はこの南殿をいう。
sen.e: The small Hojuji-dono Palace was Nan-den.
The small Hojuji-dono Palace was Nan-den.
The small Hojuji-dono Palace was Nan-den.

sen.j: 南殿には上皇のすまいとともに、東小御堂、不動堂、千手堂がたちならび、広大な池もあった。
sen.e: In addition to the Retired Emperor's residence, Nan-den Palace also contained the Higashi Komi-do Hall, Fudo-do Hall and Senju-do Hall, and a large pond.
In addition to the Retired Emperor's residence, Nan-den Palace also contained the Higashi Komi-do Hall, Fudo-do Hall and Senju-do Hall, and a large pond.
In addition to the Retired Emperor's residence, Nan-den Palace also contained the Higashi Komi-do Hall, Fudo-do Hall and Senju-do Hall, and a large pond.

sen.j: 1163年(長寛元年)には、三十三間堂（三十三間堂）が平清盛の寄進で南殿の北側に造立された。
sen.e: In 1163, Sanjusangen-do Hall was built to the north of Nan-den Palace using funds donated by TAIRA no Kiyomori.
In 1163, Sanjusangen-do Hall was built to the north of Nan-den Palace using funds donated by TAIRA no Kiyomori.
In 1163, Sanjusangen-do Hall was built to the north of Nan-den Palace using funds donated by TAIRA no Kiyomori.

sen.j: また新日吉神社、新熊野本宮も法住寺殿内に建立された。
sen.e: Ima Hie-jinja Shrine and Ima Kumano-hongu Shrine were also constructed in Hoju-ji Temple.
Ima Hie-jinja Shrine and Ima Kumano-hongu Shrine were also constructed in Hoju-ji Temple.
Ima Hie-jinja Shrine and Ima Kumano-hongu Shrine were also constructed in Hoju-ji Temple.

sen.j: 1176年（安元2年）後白河上皇の女御建春門院（平滋子）が亡くなると、女御の御陵として法華堂が建てられた。
sen.e: The Hokke-do Hall was constructed as the tomb of Kenshunmon-in (TAIRA no Shigeko), court lady of Retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa, after she died in 1176.
The Hokke-do Hall was constructed as the tomb of Kenshunmon-in (TAIRA no Shigeko), court lady of Retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa, after she died in 1176.
The Hokke-do Hall was constructed as the tomb of Kenshunmonin (TAIRA no Shigeko), court lady of the Retired Emperor Goshirakawa, after she died in 1176.
sen.cmt: 「建春門院」は女性の院号のため、Kenshunmoninとし、the Retired Emperor Goshirakawaとしました。

sen.j: 上皇と平家の栄華を象徴する法住寺殿ではあったが、1183年(寿永2年)木曾義仲の軍勢によって南殿に火がかけられ（法住寺合戦）、上皇は北の門から新日吉神社へむけ輿にのって逃亡、以後上皇は六条西洞院の長講堂に移りそこで生涯をおえる。
sen.e: Hojuji-dono Palace came to symbolize the glory of the Retired Emperor and the Taira family, but Nan-den was set ablaze in 1183 by Yoshinaka KISO's forces (Siege of Hojuji-dono Palace), the Retired Emperor escaped to Ima Hie-jinja Shrine in a palanquin and later moved to Rokujo Nishinoto-in Temple's Choko-do Hall where he lived out the remainder of his life.

Hojuji-dono Palace came to symbolize the glory of the Retired Emperor and the Taira family, but Nan-den was set ablaze in 1183 by Yoshinaka KISO's forces (Siege of Hojuji-dono Palace), the Retired Emperor escaped to Ima Hie-jinja Shrine in a palanquin and later moved to Rokujo Nishinoto-in Temple's Choko-do Hall where he lived out the remainder of his life.

Hojuji-dono Palace came to symbolize the glory of the Retired Emperor and the Taira family, but Nan-den was set ablaze in 1183 by Yoshinaka KISO's forces (Siege of Hojuji-dono Palace), the Retired Emperor escaped to Ima Hie-jinja Shrine in a palanquin and later moved to Rokujo Nishinoto-in Temple's Choko-do Hall where he lived out the remainder of his life.

sen.j: 1192年(建久3年)後白河上皇の死により、焼失した法住寺殿の敷地にあらたに法華堂がつくられ、上皇の御陵とさだめられた。
sen.e: Following the death of Retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa in 1192, Hokke-do Hall was reconstructed on the site of the former Hojuji-dono Palace and became his tomb.
Following the death of Retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa in 1192, Hokke-do Hall was reconstructed on the site of the former Hojuji-dono Palace and became his tomb.
Following the death of the Retired Emperor Goshirakawa in 1192, Hokke-do Hall was reconstructed on the site of the former Hojuji-dono Palace and became his tomb.
sen.cmt: the Retired Emperor Goshirakawaとしました。

sen.j: この法華堂は建春門院の法華堂の南側にあたり、蓮華王院（三十三間堂）に対面して二堂が並立していたと推定されている。
sen.e: This Hokke-do Hall was situated to the south of Kenshunmon-in's Hokke-do Hall, and it is assumed that the two halls stood side-by-side facing Rengeo-in Temple (Sanjusangen-do).
This Hokke-do Hall was situated to the south of Kenshunmon-in's Hokke-do Hall, and it is assumed that the two halls stood side-by-side facing Rengeo-in Temple (Sanjusangen-do).
This Hokke-do Hall was situated to the south of Kenshunmonin's Hokke-do Hall, and it is assumed that the two halls stood side-by-side facing Rengeo-in Temple (Sanjusangen-do).
sen.cmt: Kenshunmon-in’sのアポストロフィーを半角に、およびKenshunmoninに修正

sen.j: 建春門院の法華堂は14世紀には破損がひどかったという記録があり（『花園天皇宸記』）、現在は、後白河上皇の法華堂のみが残っている。
sen.e: It was recorded in the diary of Emperor Hanazono that Kenshunmon-in Temple's Hokke-do Hall became severely damaged in the 14th century, and now only the Hokke-do Hall of retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa remains.

It was recorded in the diary of Emperor Hanazono that Kenshunmon-in Temple's Hokke-do Hall became severely damaged in the 14th century, and now only the Hokke-do Hall of retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa remains.

It was recorded in the diary of Emperor Hanazono that Kenshunmonin's Hokke-do Hall became severely damaged in the 14th century, and now only the Hokke-do Hall of the retired Emperor Goshirakawa remains.
sen.cmt: Kenshunmon-in Temple's Hokke-do→Kenshunmonin's Hokke-doに修正、the Retired Emperor Goshirakawaとしました。

tit.j: 鎌倉期から江戸末期まで
tit.e: From the Kamakura Period to the Edo Period
From the Kamakura Period to the Edo Period
From the Kamakura Period to the end of the Edo Period

sen.j: その後法住寺は後白河天皇の御陵をまもる寺として長く存続した。
sen.e: Hoju-ji Temple long continued to exist to protect the tomb of Emperor Go-Shirakawa.
Hoju-ji Temple long continued to exist to protect the tomb of Emperor Go-Shirakawa.
Hoju-ji Temple long continued to exist to protect the tomb of Emperor Goshirakawa.

sen.j: 前述のごとく鎌倉時代までは建春門院をまつる法華堂、後白河上皇をまつる法華堂が、蓮華王院の東にならびたっていた。
sen.e: As stated above, the Hokke-do enshrining Kenshunmon-in and the Hokke-do enshrining Retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa stood alongside one another to the west of Rengeo-in Temple.
As stated above, the Hokke-do enshrining Kenshunmon-in and the Hokke-do enshrining Retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa stood alongside one another to the west of Rengeo-in Temple.
As stated above, the Hokke-do enshrining Kenshunmon-in and the Hokke-do enshrining the Retired Emperor Goshirakawa stood alongside one another to the west of Rengeo-in Temple.

sen.j: 時の権力の変遷にともなって法住寺はいくつかの近隣寺院と関係をもった。
sen.e: Hoju-ji Temple became connected to several temples as power changed hands over the years.
Hoju-ji Temple became connected to several temples as power changed hands over the years.
Hoju-ji Temple became connected to several temples as power changed hands over the years.

sen.j: とくに妙法院との関係は密接で、後白河上皇が比叡山の妙法院を京都に移した際、妙法院住職に法住寺、新日吉神社を付託し門跡寺院としたという機縁がある。
sen.e: The connection to Myoho-in Temple was so close that when Retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa relocated Mt. Hiei's Myoho-in Temple to Kyoto, the head priest of Myoho-in Temple would be sent to Ima Hie-jinja Shrine and Hoju-ji Temple, and there was a chance that is could be considered a Monzeki Temple (a temple traditionally served by head priest related to the Imperial family).

The connection to Myoho-in Temple was so close that when Retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa relocated Mt. Hiei's Myoho-in Temple to Kyoto, the head priest of Myoho-in Temple would be sent to Ima Hie-jinja Shrine and Hoju-ji Temple, and there was a chance that is could be considered a Monzeki Temple (a temple traditionally served by head priest related to the Imperial family).

The connection to Myoho-in Temple was so close that when the Retired Emperor Goshirakawa relocated Myoho-in Temple on Mt. Hiei to Kyoto, the head priest of Myoho-in Temple would be sent to Ima Hie-jinja Shrine and Hoju-ji Temple, and there was a chance that is could be considered a Monzeki Temple (a temple traditionally served by head priest related to the Imperial family).
sen.cmt: the Retired Emperor Goshirakawaに修正、Mt. Hiei's Myoho-in Temple→Myoho-in Temple on Mt. Hieiとしました。

sen.j: 豊臣政権下では、すぐ北にあった方広寺(大仏)が法住寺や蓮華王院の寺域を包摂するということもあったが、徳川政権によって妙法院が重要視されるようになると、妙法院と一体視され、法住寺は妙法院門跡の｢院家｣として待遇された。
sen.e: Under the Toyotomi government, the territory of the temple came to include the precincts of Hoko-ji Temple (Great Buddha) immediately to the north and Rengeo-in Temple, but Myoho-in Temple was highly regarded by the Tokugawa government and Hoju-ji Temple became treated as an "inge" (branch temple that supports the main temple) of Myoho-in Monzeki Temple.

Under the Toyotomi government, the territory of the temple came to include the precincts of Hoko-ji Temple (Great Buddha) immediately to the north and Rengeo-in Temple, but Myoho-in Temple was highly regarded by the Tokugawa government and Hoju-ji Temple became treated as an "inge" (branch temple that supports the main temple) of Myoho-in Monzeki Temple.

Under the Toyotomi government, the territory of the temple came to include the precincts of Hoko-ji Temple (Great Buddha) immediately to the north and Rengeo-in Temple, but Myoho-in Temple was highly regarded by the Tokugawa government and Hoju-ji Temple became treated as an 'inge' (branch temple that supports the main temple) of Myoho-in Monzeki Temple.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更

sen.j: 妙法院の日記である『妙法院日次記』には、江戸時代を通じて、法住寺の名前があがっている。
sen.e: In the Myoho-in Temple diary entitled "Myoho-in Nichijiki", the name 'Hoju-ji Temple' becomes more prominent throughout the Edo period.
In the Myoho-in Temple diary entitled "Myoho-in Nichijiki", the name 'Hoju-ji Temple' becomes more prominent throughout the Edo period.
In the Myoho-in Temple diary entitled "Myoho-in Nichijiki", the name 'Hoju-ji Temple' becomes more prominent throughout the Edo period.
sen.cmt: ‘Hoju-ji Temple’のクォーテーションを半角に修正

sen.j: また現在は法住寺と分離されている隣接の後白河天皇陵内に『法住寺』と書かれた江戸時代の手水鉢があり、後白河天皇の陵を継続してまもってきたことが知られる。
sen.e: It is known that Hoju-ji Temple continued to protect the adjacent tomb of Emperor Go-Shirakawa and, although the tomb is now separate from the temple, it has a water basin with the words "Hoju-ji Temple" written on it.

It is known that Hoju-ji Temple continued to protect the adjacent tomb of Emperor Go-Shirakawa and, although the tomb is now separate from the temple, it has a water basin with the words "Hoju-ji Temple" written on it.

It is known that Hoju-ji Temple continued to protect the adjacent tomb of Emperor Goshirakawa and, although the tomb is now separate from the temple, it has a water basin with the words "Hoju-ji Temple" written on it.

sen.j: なお妙法院に住持した歴代法親王（門跡）の墓所も法住寺境内にあった。
sen.e: The graves of the sucessive Imperial princes (Monzeki) who served at Myoho-in Temple were also in the precinct of Hoju-ji Temple.
The graves of the sucessive Imperial princes (Monzeki) who served at Myoho-in Temple were also in the precinct of Hoju-ji Temple.
The graves of the sucessive cloistered Imperial princes (Monzeki) who served at Myoho-in Temple were also in the precincts of Hoju-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 統一事項に基づき「法親王」→"cloistered Imperial princes"に修正しました。precinct→precinctsとしました。

sen.j: また元禄期には大石良雄がこの法住寺に参拝したと伝えられ、その縁から四十七士木造も安置されている。
sen.e: Wooden statues of the Forty-seven Ronin are also housed at the temple as it is said that Yoshio OISHI visited Hoju-ji Temple during the Genroku period.
Wooden statues of the Forty-seven Ronin are also housed at the temple as it is said that Yoshio OISHI visited Hoju-ji Temple during the Genroku period.
Wooden statues of the Forty-seven Ronin are also housed at the temple as it is said that Yoshio OISHI visited Hoju-ji Temple during the Genroku era.

sen.j: 幕末に法住寺陵が後白河天皇の御陵ではないと唱えた学者が現れたとき、当時の住持が御陵の真下を掘ったところ記録どおりに天皇の遺骨を納めた石櫃が見つかったと言われている。
sen.e: When scholars emerged at the end of the Edo period claiming that the tomb at Hoju-ji Temple was not that of Emperor Go-Shirakawa, it is said that the head priest at the time dug under the tomb and discovered a cist containing the remains of the Emperor just as the records described.

When scholars emerged at the end of the Edo period claiming that the tomb at Hoju-ji Temple was not that of Emperor Go-Shirakawa, it is said that the head priest at the time dug under the tomb and discovered a cist containing the remains of the Emperor just as the records described.

When scholars emerged at the end of the Edo period claiming that the tomb at Hoju-ji Temple was not that of Emperor Goshirakawa, it is said that the head priest at the time dug under the tomb and discovered a cist containing the remains of the Emperor just as the records described.

sen.j: 明治初頭から現在
sen.e: From the Beginning of the Meiji Period to the Present
From the Beginning of the Meiji Period to the Present
From the Beginning of the Meiji Period to the Present

sen.j: 明治期にはいると、後白河天皇稜と妙法院門跡法親王の墓所が寺域から分離され、宮内省の管轄におかれた。
sen.e: In the Meiji era, the tomb of Emperor Go-Shirakawa and the graves of the Myoho-in Temple Monzeki princes were separated from the temple grounds and placed under the jurisdiction of the Department of the Imperial Household.

In the Meiji era, the tomb of Emperor Go-Shirakawa and the graves of the Myoho-in Temple Monzeki princes were separated from the temple grounds and placed under the jurisdiction of the Department of the Imperial Household.

In the Meiji period, the tomb of Emperor Goshirakawa and the graves of the Myoho-in Temple Monzeki princes were separated from the temple grounds and placed under the jurisdiction of the Department of the Imperial Household.
sen.cmt: the Meiji period, Emperor Goshirakawaに修正

sen.j: 明治の初め、東山渋谷にあった仏光寺から親鸞ゆかりとされる阿弥陀像や、親鸞の木造(そば喰いの像)がうつされている。
sen.e: At the beginning of the Meiji era, a statue of Amida (Amitabha), thought to be connected to Shinran, and a wooden statue of Shinran (statue depicting him eating soba noodles) were relocated to the temple from Bukko-ji Temple in Shibutani, Higashiyama.

At the beginning of the Meiji era, a statue of Amida (Amitabha), thought to be connected to Shinran, and a wooden statue of Shinran (statue depicting him eating soba noodles) were relocated to the temple from Bukko-ji Temple in Shibutani, Higashiyama.

At the beginning of the Meiji period, a statue of Amida (Amitabha), thought to be connected to Shinran, and a wooden statue of Shinran (statue depicting him eating soba noodles) were relocated to the temple from Bukko-ji Temple in Shibutani, Higashiyama.

sen.j: 法住寺は明治期から昭和にかけて『大興徳院』と寺名が改称されたが、1955年(昭和30年)法住寺に復名。
sen.e: Hoju-ji Temple was known as "Daikotoku-in Temple" from the Meiji era to the Showa era but its original name was restored in 1955.
Hoju-ji Temple was known as "Daikotoku-in Temple" from the Meiji era to the Showa era but its original name was restored in 1955.
Hoju-ji Temple was known as "Daikotoku-in Temple" from the Meiji period to the Showa period but its original name was restored in 1955.
sen.cmt: the Meiji period, the Showa periodに修正

sen.j: 明治時代初頭に後白河天皇陵をまもるという役割は形式上はおわったが、陵におかれている後白河上皇像の模作を1991年(平成3年)に造立し安置するなど、現在でも密接な関係をもっている。
sen.e: The temple's role of protecting the tomb of Emperor Go-Shirakawa ceremonially came to an end in the early Meiji era, but maintains a close connection and also has a replica of the statue of the Emperor housed within the tomb that was created in 1991.

The temple's role of protecting the tomb of Emperor Go-Shirakawa ceremonially came to an end in the early Meiji era, but maintains a close connection and also has a replica of the statue of the Emperor housed within the tomb that was created in 1991.

The temple's role of protecting the tomb of Emperor Goshirakawa ceremonially came to an end in the early Meiji era, but maintains a close connection and also has a replica of the statue of the Emperor housed within the tomb that was created in 1991.

sen.j: また上皇が愛した今様の歌合せも復元して行われている。
sen.e: Also, the modern style poetry contests that were much enjoyed by the Retired Emperor continue to be held at the temple.
Also, the modern style poetry contests that were much enjoyed by the Retired Emperor continue to be held at the temple.
Also, Imayo (a type of poetry, popular in the Heian period) Utaawase (poetry contests) that were much enjoyed by the Retired Emperor continue to be held at the temple.
sen.cmt: 今様→Imayo (a type of poetry, popular in the Heian period)、歌合せ→Utaawase (poetry contests)としました。

tit.e: Emperor Go-Shirakawa Tomb at Hoju-ji Temple

sen.j: 法住寺と隣接する。

sen.j: 1月15日 無病息災大根炊き（不動明王に備えた大根を大鍋で炊いて接待）
sen.e: January 15: Mubyosokusai Daikondaki (a daikon radish prepared for Fudo Myoo is cooked in a large pot and served)
January 15: Mubyosokusai Daikondaki (a daikon radish prepared for Fudo Myoo is cooked in a large pot and served)

sen.j: 5月2日 後白河院御聖忌法要（5月1日～7日には後白河上皇の木像が開扉公開される）

sen.e: December 14th: Gishi Taisai (Buddhist memorial service followed by a tea offering ceremony and the serving of Uchiiri Soba ("raid" buckwheat noodles))
